newsitem.title: USA: Ehrlich says corrected trade report adds to Q1.
newsitem.headline: Ehrlich says corrected trade report adds to Q1.

text.p: Commerce Undersecretary Everett Ehrlich on Friday said the reduction in the February trade deficit from what was first reported will add a few tenths of a percent to the estimate of first quarter growth.
Interviewed on Reuters Financial Television, Ehrlich said the GDP number for the first quarter is going to be large, estimating it will show an increase of 4.0 percent or more.

The department on Thursday after correcting for "reporting errors" on oil imports, said the February deficit actually dropped from $12.67 billion in January to $10.4 billion rather than the $11.59 billion reported earlier.
"It will take GDP estimates up...a few tenths perhaps," he said, adding that the GDP number for the first quarter is going to be larger that the 3.8 percent growth achieved in the fourth quarter.
"It could well start with a four from what we see to date," Ehrlich said.
Asked about the strong dollar, he said that he hoped that the Japanese authorities did not use it as an excuse to back away from reform efforts.
"Our concern about the dollar is that it not be a pretext for a softening commitment for trade liberalization," he said.
He said it would be bad news for the Japanese to raise interest rates at this time as suggested by some as a way of strengthening the yen, bringing it more in line with its long term value.
He said this could also be accomplished by deregulation in the financial sector since it would allow capital to flow into Japan.

In the interview, Ehrlich blamed a miscommunication between the Customs Service that accumulates the oil import data although to "some extent it is an artifact of a pencil and paper environment that we've got to leave very soon."

He said the administration has a plan to automate export and import declarations in a way that would do away with the potential for this kind of error but "Congress needs to fund it and exporters particularly need to embrace it."
